channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Without Shimon Peres? In Many Ways, His Dream Faded Long Ago
item.media:description: Israeli flags were lowered to half staff outside the Parliament in Jerusalem on Wednesday after Shimon Peres died.
item.description: Despite his own late-in-life attempts at unity among Israelis, perhaps it is only natural that his legacy is viewed through a prism of old divides.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: A Bomb Shatters an Aleppo Building, and Videos Capture the Rescue Minute by Minute
item.description: Videos show people trying to save those trapped under rubble in an area where basic services have been devastated by years of war.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and YARA BISHARA

item.title: Haitian Men Cut Off From Families as U.S. Tightens Entry Rules
item.media:description: “I’m hoping God makes miracles,” said Sandra Alexandre, with her newborn baby, Nova Vitoria Dieumercy, at a hotel in San Diego on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.description: After the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, many Haitians were allowed into the United States on humanitarian grounds. Now, a sudden policy shift is dividing families.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Abroad in America: Parsing What Makes a Trump Supporter Tick
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump on Monday in Hempstead, N.Y., during the first presidential debate with Hillary Clinton.
item.description: Readers emailing from abroad are surprised by the campaign’s bluster. They don’t understand how a race for the American presidency can be dominated by arguments over “birtherism” and beauty queens.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Dutch Inquiry Links Russia to 298 Deaths in Explosion of Jetliner Over Ukraine
item.description: A Dutch-led investigation concluded that Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine asked for and received a surface-to-air missile that was used to shoot down the plane in 2014.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Duterte, Philippine President, Raises Doubts About Military Alliance With U.S.
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.
item.description: Defense and diplomatic officials were facing a quandary after the president vowed to end military exercises with the U.S. and strengthen ties with China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Antigraft Law Stirs Up Wariness Over South Koreans Bearing Gifts
item.media:description: The senior prosecutor Jin Kyung-joon, center, was arrested in July on charges of taking millions of dollars in bribes from the owner of an online game company, deepening suspicions about corruption among high-ranking law enforcement officials.
item.description: The measure, which affects public servants, journalists and teachers, will alter a country where meals, cash and other gifts have long been central to doing business.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bulgarian Shakes Up Race for U.N. Leader
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, a Bulgarian diplomat who has entered the race to be the next United Nations secretary general, in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2012.
item.media:credit: Sven Torfinn for The New York Times
item.description: The addition of a second Bulgarian candidate, Kristalina Georgieva, could alter the calculus between the West and Russia over who replaces Ban Ki-moon as secretary general.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA

item.title: International Court Takes a Stand With Ruling on Destruction of Antiquities
item.media:description: The rubble of the Temple of Bel in Palmyra, Syria, which was almost completely demolished by the Islamic State group.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague, in ruling that the destruction of cultural antiquities is a war crime, sent a signal, even if further prosecutions appear unlikely for the time being.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Report Accuses Sudan of ‘Scorched Earth’ Tactics in Darfur
item.media:description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan at a rally in Darfur this month. He has been indicted on charges of genocide, but the International Criminal Court suspended the case because world powers have not moved to arrest him.
item.description: Amnesty International said government forces had laid waste to villages this year in an area known as Jebel Marra, burning homes, looting livestock and raping women.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas to Attend Shimon Peres Funeral, but Thaw With Israel Is Unlikely
item.description: The decision by Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, to attend the Israeli statesman’s funeral does not portend reconciliation with Israel.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Joseph Harmatz, Who Led Jewish Plot to Kill Germans After World War II, Dies at 91
item.media:description: Investigators in Nuremberg, Germany, examined the hiding place where arsenic was found in 1946 in a bakery that supplied captured SS officers.
item.media:credit: U.S. Army Signal Corps, via Associated Press
item.description: Harmatz, a survivor of the Vilnius ghetto in Lithuania, was the leader of a group that poisoned 2,200 imprisoned Germans by lacing their bread with arsenic.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Moscow Journal: Muscovites Learn to Love Traffic Rules. Some See Proof of Dictatorship.
item.media:description: A street in Moscow. In a city where traffic rules used to be viewed as optional, respect for crossing signals has grown.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: As with so much of what happens in Russia, interpreting the new civility on the roads depends on what you make of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Reykjavik Briefly Swaps Its City Lights for Northern Ones
item.description: The Icelandic capital went dark Wednesday night, after the City Council switched off street lamps and encouraged residents to turn off their lights.
item.dc:creator: PAULINE BOCK

item.title: Russia Rejects U.S. Demands for Resumption of Syria Cease-Fire
item.media:description: The site of an airstrike by government helicopters on a rebel-held neighborhood in Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Syrian Civil Defense White Helmets, via Associated Press
item.description: Moscow offered a 48-hour “pause” in fighting, far less than the minimum of seven days the Americans have demanded.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Chengguan, Widely Despised Officers in China, Find Refuge and a Kind Ear
item.media:description: Chengguan, or urban management officers, confiscating fruit from a street vendor in Beijing in June.
item.description: In recognition of the pressures they face, a center opened in Nanjing that offers the urban management officers counseling and other support services.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: India Claims ‘Surgical Strikes’ Across Line of Control in Kashmir
item.description: Pakistan played down the early morning operation, which it said killed two of its soldiers and wounded nine, calling it a propaganda exercise by Delhi.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: North Korean Soldier Crosses DMZ to Defect, South Says
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers patrolling near the border with the North in January.
item.description: South Korea said officials were debriefing the soldier to determine his motive for leaving the North.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Leader of Spain’s Socialist Party Survives Ouster Attempt
item.media:description: Pedro Sánchez
item.description: The future of the main opposition party’s leader, Pedro Sánchez, still hangs in the balance, after top party officials said they would resign in protest.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Obama and Shimon Peres: Fast Friends Who Found Peace Out of Reach
item.media:description: President Obama with Shimon Peres at a state dinner in Jerusalem in March 2013 after Mr. Peres bestowed on him Israel’s Presidential Medal of Distinction.
item.description: They were an international odd couple with seemingly little in common when they first met, but somehow Barack Obama and Mr. Peres hit it off.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: The Interpreter: Russia’s Brutal Bombing of Aleppo May Be Calculated, and It May Be Working
item.media:description: Civilians and rescuers at the site of an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.
item.description: Many analysts say Russia and the Syrian government could be massacring civilians as part of a strategy with aims beyond just one city.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In Battle for Soul of Britain’s Labour Party, a Leftist Group Is Winning
item.media:description: Delegates at the Labour Party annual conference in Liverpool, England, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Jeremy Corbyn’s strengthened hold on the Labour Party is due in large part to the success of Momentum, a group intent on bringing true socialism to Britain.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: U.S. to Send 600 More Troops to Iraq to Help Retake Mosul From ISIS
item.media:description: American and British soldiers at the Basmaya base southeast of Baghdad in January.
item.description: The deployment, to aid Iraqis in the looming battle to take back Mosul from the Islamic State, will bring the number of American troops in Iraq to 5,000.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Syria Talks Will End if Aleppo Bombing Continues, U.S. Tells Russia
item.media:description: Aleppo’s citadel as seen through destruction on Wednesday in the Farafira district. The Syrian army took control of the rebel-held district after days of heavy airstrikes.
item.description: The warning from Secretary of State John Kerry came on the same day that two hospitals in insurgent-held areas of the city were hit by airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Iranian Women’s Rights Activist Is Given 16-Year Sentence
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi in Tehran in 2008.
item.description: The battles with the judiciary of Narges Mohammadi, a human rights lawyer, highlight the severe stress women’s rights activists face in Iran.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Obama and Bill Clinton to Travel to Israel to Honor Shimon Peres
item.media:description: Shimon Peres with President Obama in the Oval Office in 2011. Mr. Obama, former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State John Kerry are expected to attend Mr. Peres’s funeral on Friday.
item.description: Presidents, prime ministers and a prince accepted invitations to the funeral on Friday for Mr. Peres, one of the country’s elder statesmen.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Hongwansi Journal: Modern Life Presents Nomads of China’s Highlands With a ‘Tragic Choice’
item.media:description: A Buddhist monk, Nanqian, who is an ethnic Yugur, at the Hongwansi temple in Gansu Province, China. Nanqian is the only lama living year-round at the temple.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The Yugurs are struggling to maintain the language and culture that distinguish them as a people, the products of centuries of swirling Asian history.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: A Chinese Scholar on the Changing World of the Yugur Nomads
item.media:description: A Yugur sheep herder in Gansu Province, northern China. In recent years, the central government has tried to resettle the traditionally nomadic Yugurs in more permanent homes.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A traditions of the nomadic herders are fading as the government restricts grazing on the grasslands and promotes the move to more permanent homes.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Airstrike in Eastern Afghanistan Kills at Least 13
item.media:description: Treating a wounded man in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, after an airstrike on Wednesday. A United States military spokesman called it a counterterrorism strike, but residents said the victims were civilians.
item.description: An American military spokesman said a “counterterrorism airstrike” had taken place in the area. Afghan officials said the victims were members of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: KHALID ALOKOZAY and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Under Pressure, Amnesty International Cancels Briefing on Torture in Thailand
item.description: The rights group had planned to present a report in Bangkok accusing the ruling junta, but the police said the group’s employees would breach Thai labor law.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: Explaining the U.S. Presidential Election to China: It’s Not Really Like ‘House of Cards’
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton at their first presidential debate. More Chinese than ever appear interested in the American election, though many find it confusing.
item.description: A founder of the podcast “Xuanmei,” or “U.S. Election,” says the Chinese are more interested in the American election than ever but don’t always understand it.
item.dc:creator: CAO LI

item.title: What in the World: Medicinal Herb or Myth? Indian Official Proposes Hunt for Sanjivani of Lore
item.description: A state official wants to spend nearly $4 million in search of the plant, which is said to grow in the Himalayas and which a Hindu epic claims has the power to revive the dying.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: What in the World: Cold Cases: Crime and Punishment in Antarctica
item.media:description: Russian and Chilean researchers drinking homemade vodka at the Bellingshausen Antarctic base. Drinking is common on such bases and contributes to fights.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: How are crimes handled where there are no permanent courts, prisons or police forces? Under the Antarctic Treaty, countries police their own.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Free-Speech Fatality
item.media:description: Supporters of the Jordanian writer Nahed Hattar protesting his death in Amman, Jordan, this month.
item.description: The Jordanian government claims it’s fighting radicalization but at the same time offers concessions to radicals. And the result is deadly.
item.dc:creator: LINA EJEILAT

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Peres and the Passing of Hope
item.media:description: Prime Minister Netanyahu observed a moment of silence at the start of a special cabinet meeting to mourn the death of Shimon Peres.
item.description: Shimon Peres thought about history. Netanyahu thinks about the next election.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hungary’s Duty to Refugees
item.media:description: The Hungarian police standing guard this month along the border with Serbia as construction workers finished a border fence near Roszke, Hungary.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Nearly 60 years ago, Europe sheltered Hungarian patriots fleeing Soviet repression. That humanitarian impulse must be honored today.
item.dc:creator: NILS MUIZNIEKS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
